name: Buddy Stiltner
text_appearance:
• Build – Broad-shouldered, sturdy; a body built less from training and more from years of carrying heavy kit and living rough.

  • Height – Slightly above average.

  • Movement – Measured, deliberate, always conserving energy. Like someone who’s learned the hard way not to waste motion.

  • Facial Description – Tired eyes and a perpetual deadpan stare; stubble shadows his jaw.

  • Notable Features – A jagged scar across his scalp where the hair doesn’t grow back, usually hidden in the mess; his helmet has a taped-on sticker reading “IF LOST RETURN TO” that draws more attention than his name does.
history:
Buddy Stiltner never planned on becoming a soldier. He grew up on a dustball colony where the biggest dreams were getting off-world and the biggest fears were debt collectors showing up before payday. When the bills piled higher than his father’s drinking and his mother’s stubborn pride, Buddy signed on with the only outfit hiring without asking too many questions: the Mirrorsmoke Mercenary Company.

MSMC wasn’t glamorous. They weren’t elite shock troops or precision operators; they were the galaxy’s garbage men. The poor bastards sent into the meat grinder when everyone else refused the job. Buddy learned quickly that the company valued contracts more than lives, and that survival depended on two things: your squad and your own stubborn will. He wasn’t the fastest, smartest, or deadliest merc in his unit, but he endured. He carried heavy packs until his back ached, patched frames with duct tape and curses, and marched into fire because it was his only way forward.

His scar came from one of those jobs that MSMC is infamous for. A suppression contract on a mining world teetering on revolt. The brass sold it as routine, “low resistance, low risk.” In truth, the locals had been stockpiling weapons for years, and Buddy’s squad walked straight into a killing field. His squad leads frame was gutted in the first barrage, the canopy torn open like a tin can. Shrapnel cut across his scalp scarring him. For hours he lay trapped beneath the wreckage.

When he finally came to, the battle was over. His squad was dead. Retrieval crews had written the site off as a total loss, and Buddy would’ve been just another unclaimed body if not for sheer coincidence; a Union patrol passing through picked up his fading lifesigns. They dragged him out of the mud, half-dead but breathing.

He earned the callsign “Lucky.” At first, it was a joke. Surviving a massacre wasn’t luck, it was just bad timing that left him behind. But the name stuck. Buddy kept surviving when others didn’t. Shuttle crashes, ambushes, collapsing habs. Every time he should’ve died, he walked away with another scar, another story, and fewer friends. To his comrades, it made him charmed. To Buddy, it was just cruel chance, the universe refusing to let him off the hook.

When his term finally ended, Buddy didn’t re-up. Union was recruiting veterans with licenses and field experience, and he took the first offer out. Compared to MSMC, Union training was a vacation: real food, real med care, and commanders who actually gave a damn whether you lived to see the next drop. Buddy adapted, but he never shed the edge Mirrorsmoke had carved into him. Where others talk about ideals and duty, he sees casualty numbers and operational risks. Where others dream of glory, he dreams of getting through a mission without anyone left behind.

Now Union has him on assignment to Cressidium, his first official deployment as a Lancer pilot. The mission is straightforward on paper. Bodyguard detail. Buddy doesn’t complain. He’ll keep his charge breathing, because that’s the job. But deep down, he knows better than to trust a clean briefing. He’s "Lucky" Stiltner, after all. And luck, in his experience, always comes with a cost.

systems.flavorDescription: By installing additional armor plating, redundant firing circuits, and enhanced insulation to magazines the longevity of a frame’s armaments can be greatly enhanced.
The use of turret drones is a rather traditional form of force multiplication – one that has remained the backbone of defense in many theaters.

weapon.flavorDescription:
Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-II (T-2) line displays GMS’s proprietary “charged” melee weapons and energy weapons.

Much like GMS mechs, GMS weapons are reliable galactic standards, made using interchangeable parts and built to withstand almost any conditions. There are three lines currently in production.
The Type-III (T-3) line is made up of heavy weapons, ordnance, and other exotic, specialized, or massive weapons. A broad classification, the T-3 range includes conventional-kinetic anti-materiel rifles, super-rapid cycling pulse rifles, missile racks, cannons, and drone nexuses – “hive”style launchers that serve as miniature factory, hangar, and deployment systems for portable drones. The classification also includes the fearsome “segment knife”, a system that uses flash-printing to produce disposable edged weapons in a vicinity around the user.

This oversized, chassis-mounted artillery platform is capable of unleashing a devastating barrage. With a short maximum range for a weapon of its kind, it is nevertheless capable of saturating a targeted area in a harrowing hail of intelligent self-correcting cluster munitions. It is currently carried in the “Storm” line of superheavy equipment.
Gained from the "Engineer" Rank I Talent

reserves.name: Sniper Team
reserves.label: Resource
reserves.description: LSA ground forces and Union marines are getting a crash-course in joint operations on this mission, and nothing builds teamwork like target shooting. You can spend this reserve at the start of any combat to call upon a nearby sniper team to provide you with fire support. For the rest of the scene, each time you take the Lock On Quick Tech action, your target takes 2 AP kinetic damage.

armor.flavorDescription: These hardsuits, common among military units, feature heavier plating than light hardsuits but more mobility than heavy hardsuits. They are powered, augmenting the user’s strength, and typically feature an onboard computer, sensor suite, integrated air, burst EVA system, and waste recycling systems.

weapons.flavorDescription: Light signature weapons might be oversized revolvers, braces of pistols, and submachine guns.

gear.flavorDescription: These clamps attach easily to any metal surface, enhancing maneuverability in zero-g environments or when repairing mechs. They can be carried or fitted to boots.
This clear, plastic-like sheet can be placed over the wounds of severely injured pilots. It instantly begins to stabilize them, injecting medicine and deploying nanites to stitch wounds shut.
